s1: Computational Methods for Network Science covers the essentials of using computational approaches to pose and answer social science research problems.
s2: Understand, apply, and analyse state and state machines in expressing computations.

s1: In doing so it also covers a selected set of network algorithms in depth.
s2: Apply fundamental programming concepts for medium scale programs.

s1: This includes random graph models, homophily and friendship paradox, influence and contagion in networks, markets and network games, network resilence.
s2: The course also covers more advanced data structures, such as priority queues, B-trees, red-black trees, and AVL trees, and deepens understanding of appropriate algorithmic strategies.

s1: Furthermore, it also teaches students about the ethics of doing data-driven social science research.
s2: The course also treats intellectual property considerations in software development and deployment.

s1: The course equips the students with in-depth knowledge and hands-on experience in working with network data to study social processes at both the individual and aggregate levels.
s2: This course continues to build on topics taught in the previous two courses. It focuses on construction of medium scale programs, using design patterns and tools that are used in the software development process.

s1: Graduates will be equipped with the technical, theoretical and conceptual skills and knowledge to start a budding career in this field of research.
s2: Contrast the concepts of copyright, patenting, and trademarks as mechanisms for protecting intellectual property, within the legal context for these mechanisms;  understand, analyse, and evaluate ethical/social tradeoffs in technical decisions, evaluating stakeholder positions.

s1: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles of using computational approaches to formulate and answer social science questions.
s2: Understand fundamental concepts of GUIs and user interfaces; understand the basics of modeling and simulation.

s1: Demonstrate a working understanding in the ethical concerns of data drive analysis and experiments in human behavior.
s2: Contrast the concepts of copyright, patenting, and trademarks as mechanisms for protecting intellectual property, within the legal context for these mechanisms;  understand, analyse, and evaluate ethical/social tradeoffs in technical decisions, evaluating stakeholder positions.

s1: Apply network analysis algorithms in practical contexts.
s2: Apply fundamental programming concepts for medium scale programs.

s1: Analyze results from network algorithms, and articulate their limitations.
s2: Understand, apply, and analyse state and state machines in expressing computations.

s1: Communicate the process of formulating and solving computational social science problems to a team of professionals with computing and/or social sciences.
s2: The course also treats intellectual property considerations in software development and deployment.
